news.title: South Africa: Country's Problems Lie in Political Negligence, Not Its Constitution
news.summary: analysis By Penelope Andrews University of Cape Town South Africa is witnessing another wave of disillusionment with the constitutional arrangement that followed the end of apartheid in 1994 As the country advances towards the third decade of…

news.title: SA's problem not its constitution
news.summary: Why has the country not made the kinds of social and economic advances that were promised in the negotiated settlement and incorporated in the 1996 constitution? South Africa’s constitution is admired globally.

news.title: The Constitution not at fault | The New Age
news.summary: South Africa is witnessing another wave of disillusionment with the constitutional arrangement that followed the end of apartheid in 1994.

news.title: South Africa: A 10-Point Plan to Accelerate Orderly Land Reform in South Africa
news.summary: analysis By Prof Quinton Johnson Nelson Mandela University A more than 365 year history of colonialism and apartheid have indelibly affected land heritage and human rights in South Africa Among the vast array of discriminatory laws was the Land Act…

news.title: South Africa: A 10-Point Plan to Accelerate Orderly Land Reform in South Africa
news.summary: analysis A more than 365 year history of colonialism and apartheid have indelibly affected land, heritage and human rights in South Africa.

news.title: 10-point plan to effect orderly, equitable land reform in SA
news.summary: President Jacob Zuma JOHANNESBURG — Land reform has become a hot topic in South Africa in 2017, especially earlier this year when Zuma proclaimed the ANC’s plan to enforce so-called ‘radical economic transformation’.

news.title: Ten-point plan to speedy land reform
news.summary: By 2012, only 7.5% of the formerly white-owned land had been transferred to black owners via land restitution.

facebook.title: South Africa's problems lie in political negligence, not its Constitution
facebook.summary: "  Arguably the land question is the most pertinent in South Africa. Not surprisingly the section of the constitution that’s viewed as the greatest impediment to “radical” economic transformation is Section 25 – the so-called property section. "
